lesson.title: Vision & Strategy
lesson.summary: This lesson covers Vision & Strategy for Product Development. We’ll also discuss how to map out your business model and different options for capturing revenue. Additionally, we’ll also talk about how to measure your progress through KPIs

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Lesson Intro

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
In this lesson, we’ll cover the following topics:
- Vision
- Strategy
- Business Models
- Competitive Analysis
- MVP
- KPIs

atoms.title: Learning Objectives
atoms.text:
## Learning objectives
- Define and craft compelling Vision
- Identify strategic areas to invest in
- Build a Business Model Canvas
- Conduct a Competitive Analysis
- Understand the importance of defining MVP
- Define KPIs

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
## Glossary
| Term | Definition |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| MVP | Minimum Viable Product. An early version of your product with minimal features that you can take to market in order to get feedback |
| KPI | Key Performance Indicator. KPIs can be used to measure the success of the products. |
| Revenue stream | A source of revenue for a company, mostly commonly transaction based or recurring events |
| Subscription | A type of revenue model that generates recurring revenue. Users pay a fee on an ongoing basis in exchange for access to your product. |
| Licensing | A revenue model that generates transaction based revenue. Users purchase a one time license to use your software on an ongoing basis |
| Pay per use | A revenue model that generates transaction based revenue. Users pay a fee every time they use your product. |
| Freemium | A revenue model that gives a small part of your product away at no cost to users with the ultimate goal of converting users to paid users in order to gain access to the full product. |
| CPC | Cost per click. |
| CPM | Cost per 1000 impressions. |
| CTR | Click through rate. |

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Vision

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 02 What Is Vision
Vision
atoms.caption: Your vision should flow down into everything that you do

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text:
**What is Vision? **    
    
- What your product looks like in its final state
- Essence of your product
- What your product does and why it matters to users
- Can be summarized in a sentence or two    

**Vision needs to tell a story about:**  
- What you’re building
- Who it’s for
- Why it matters


***Vision will impact every single aspect of your product so it is important to be thoughtful when you are crafting your vision.***

question.prompt: True or false: Vision sets the direction of the product

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 03 Creating Your Vision
Recap
atoms.text:
## Creating Vision

You’ll want to make sure that your vision is all of the following:
- Inspiring
- Ambitious
- Easy to explain
- Something the team believes in
- Something you evolve over time
- Something you share out frequently

Here are a few examples of vision:
- Google Wifi: A wireless router that people love
- Facebook: Connect with friends and the world around you
- Amazon: Earth's most customer centric company and a place where people can come to find and discover anything they might want to buy online
- [More examples](https://examples.yourdictionary.com/best-examples-of-a-vision-statement.html)

question.prompt: Which is the best example of vision?

answers.text: Re-imagine how to sell tickets online

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: Vision serves as a north star to guide the team and decision making as your product is being developed. It explains what you’re building, who it’s for, and why it matters. Vision also gets the team excited and motivated about building the product.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further readings

- [Product Vision](https://www.productplan.com/glossary/product-vision/)

- [4 Experts Reveal How to Create a Strong Product Vision](https://blog.hubspot.com/service/product-vision)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Strategy

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 04 What Is Strategy
Recap
atoms.text:
Strategy is about how you are going to realize your vision and takes the following things into account:
- User needs
- Key Features
- Competitors & Differentiation
- Business Goals
- Trends

question.prompt: True or false: Strategy is all about how you get to your vision

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 05 Creating Your Strategy
Recap
atoms.text:
When you create strategy, you want to make sure that it’s:
- A balance between features, user and market needs, and business goals
- Creating building blocks for how to get to your vision
- High level, but with a little more detail
- Goal oriented, and preferably measurable

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further readings

- [What is Good Product Strategy?](https://medium.com/@melissaperri/what-is-good-product-strategy-8d5587cb7429)

- [Product Development Strategy Defined](https://www.thisisproductmanagement.com/blog/product-strategy/)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Business Models

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text: A business model describes how a business creates, delivers, and captures value. You can create a business model canvas, which captures a number of different components that will impact your ability to create and bring a product to market, including things you need to build the product and their associated costs, the value prop for your product, and getting your product to your customers and the associated revenue streams.

atoms.title: canvas
atoms.caption: The business model canvas is a helpful tool to map out a business model, which was created by  Alexander Osterwalder.

question.prompt: A business model does which of the following:

answers.text: Models out how the business will perform

atoms.title: title
atoms.text: ## Business Model Canvas Walkthrough

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 07 Business Model Canvas
Recap
atoms.text:
The business model canvas includes the following components:

- Key Partners - help build or deliver the product to users
- Key Activities - what you need to do to build and deliver the product
- Key Resources - things that you need to build the product
- Cost Structure - cost of building the product
- Value prop - why people would want your product
- Customer Relationships - how you build relationships
- Channel - how you get the product to customers
- Customer Segments - different types of customers
- Revenue Streams - how you get money from customers

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Netflix’s value prop includes things like stream content anywhere, no ads, and the ability to watch content offline.

complex_prompt.text: Match items for Netflix into the correct components
Match items for Netflix into the correct components

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text:
There’s lots of different revenue models, but some of the most common are:
- Ads
- Purchase / Licensing
- Pay per use
- Subscription
- Freemium

question.prompt: True or false: Products must have a single revenue model

complex_prompt.text: Match each revenue source with its model

concepts.text: Revenue from third parties for showing targeted advertisements
Revenue from a single moment when a user purchases the right to use the product
Revenue whenever the user uses the product based on how much of the product was used
Revenue from a user on a continuous basis in exchange for ongoing access to the product
Access to limited parts of the product at no cost, with other parts of the product requiring revenue

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
The business model canvas is a powerful tool to understand all the components that go into creating a product, understanding its value, and how to get it to your customers.

There are also a variety of different revenue models that you can consider when creating a product. It’s important to understand how users perceive the value of your product and how they interact with your product when creating your revenue model.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further readings

- [Business Model Canvas Examples](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/knowledge/strategy/business-model-canvas-examples/)

- [10 Most Popular Startup Revenue Models](https://fi.co/insight/the-10-most-popular-startup-revenue-models)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Competitive Analysis

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text:
As part of competitive analysis, you’ll want to understand:

- Product offering and key features
- Differentiators
- Target customers
- Distribution channels
- Price points

question.prompt: What types of things could you expect to see in a competitive analysis?

question.title: Identify competitors
question.text: Think about Snapchat and identify a few competitors.

answer.text: Examples of competitors include Instagram, Telegram, Twitter, and iMessage… But there’s lots of other examples of apps that allow people to send messages to each other.

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
Competitive analysis in its simplest form is identifying other similar products in the market, including the users each product is targeting. At a high level, competitive analysis includes:

- Looking at competing products in the market
- Understanding strategy behind competing products
- Identifying strengths and weaknesses of each product
- Anticipate shifts in the market and trends

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Exercise: Competitive Analysis

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 12 Competitive Analysis Exercise
Competitive Analysis Tasks
tasks: Create a copy of this [spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1T1dmN6CMGux3yh90XgUylJs-XH-vYRWwr-UfHEysoFY/copy) to use as a template, if it’s helpful.
Outline product offering and key features for each competitor
Identify target customers for each competitor
Locate distribution channels for each competitor
Describe price points for each competitor
atoms.description:
Identify 3-5 competing fitness tracking product, and look into: 

- Product offering and key features
- Differentiators
- Target customers
- Distribution channels
- Price points

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Solution: Competitive Analysis

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 13 Competitive Analysis Exercise - Solution
competitive analysis solution
atoms.caption: An example of a competitive analysis for fitness tracking products

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## MVP

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 14 Minimum Viable Product
Recap
atoms.text:
An **MVP**, or *minimum viable product*, has just enough features to get early adopters excited. After launching an MVP, you’ll get a lot of feedback that will help you understand if you have product market fit and what areas you should invest in next


To create an MVP:
- Start with the business model canvas
- Weigh against competing solutions
- Make sure it’s aligned with business objectives
- Translate to requirements
- Identify KPIs

By definition, an MVP is only **must have** features.

question.prompt: What are the goals of building an MVP?

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: MVPs allow you to get product to market fast, get feedback from real users, and learn/fail fast.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further readings

- [What is an MVP?](https://blog.leanstack.com/minimum-viable-product-mvp-7e280b0b9418)

- [Types of MVPs and Examples](https://mlsdev.com/blog/minimum-viable-product-examples)

- [15+ Examples MVPs](https://softwarebrothers.co/blog/15-examples-of-successful-mvps/)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## KPIs

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 15 Key Performance Indicators
Recap
atoms.text:
**KPIs**, or *Key Performance Indicators*, are a type of metric that measure the performance of your product against your strategy. They capture the big picture and help you to understand how well your product is working (or isn’t working) and are aligned with business objectives. Additionally, they help to measure how changes you make to your product move the needle (or don’t)

There are different types of KPIs ranging from Business to Product to Quality to Development.

question.prompt: True or false: A metric is always a KPI
True or False: You want to have as many KPIs as possible

complex_prompt.text: Match the KPI to the type of KPI it is

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
Tips for picking KPIs:

- Don’t measure everything
- Align user, product, and business goals
- Make sure KPIs are measurable
- Use percentages and time periods when setting goals

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further readings

- [4 Things to Remember When Defining KPIs](https://blogs.oracle.com/datascience/4-things-to-remember-when-defining-kpis)

- [18 KPI Examples Explained](https://www.clearpointstrategy.com/18-key-performance-indicators/)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Exercise: KPIs

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L3 16 Key Performance Indicators Exercise
Summary
atoms.text: Identify KPIs for your fitness tracker product. Make sure to keep in mind the components that you mapped out when putting together your business model canvas. Think about how you can translate some of those things into KPIs across business, product, quality, and development dimensions.

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Continue on to Product KPIs
Thanks for your response. Continue on to Quality KPIs
Thanks for your response. Continue on to Development KPIs
Great work identifying all those KPIs! Check out my solution in the next video to see the KPIs that I identified

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Solution: KPIs

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Lesson Recap

atoms.title: Untitled
atoms.text:
You’ve reached the end of the Vision and Strategy lesson. We covered the following topics:
- Vision
- Strategy
- Business Models
- Competitive Analysis
- MVP
- KPIs


At this point, you should be able to:
- Define and craft compelling Vision
- Identify strategic areas to invest in
- Build a Business Model Canvas
- Conduct a Competitive Analysis
- Understand the importance of defining MVP
- Define KPIs
